title: How would I bring to the courts attention, that the administrator lied about paying decedent's debts and property taxes?
question: My godfather is deceased, his biological sister was appointed administrator of his estate. She filed a supplement re: Petition for Probate, stating that she went threw decedents mail, email, and important papers and found that all creditors such as utilities & property taxes have been paid. Being familiar with all his creditors and utilities, I wanted to verify if what she stated was correct. I found he still owes money for all utilities and both property taxes are delinquent. How would I bring that to the courts attention? ( Im a real party in interest according to the court. )
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Estate administration,Probate,Probate assets,Probate court
answers: Sounds like you have read a Petition for Final Distribution and have some issues with it. If you want to bring objections to the courts attention, you need to file an objection to the Petition for Final Distribution bringing up the issues you have PROOF are not true.

I would need to know where I the process you are, and if there are any upcoming hearings. You can simply appear, and object to the Petition, but you need to file a formal petition so the Judge has something to review and rule upon., If you verbally object, the court will give you a period of time to file a written objection,. While it is possible for you to act alone and prepare an Objection, I would advise you to get an attorney.
File a petition under Probate Code Section 850 and ask for an accounting of the estate. You need legal representation on this matter.
